repnme.cdata!:
Cape Verde - Energy and Water Sector Reform
            and Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Energy and Water Sector
            Reform and Development Project for Cape Verde were as
            follows: outcomes were unsatisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was substantial, the Bank performance
            was unsatisfactory, and the Borrower performance was also
            unsatisfactory. Some lessons learned included: the
            underestimation of the difficulties and risks related to
            privatization had a significant impact on project
            implementation. While there was broad agreement on the
            overall privatization scheme, there was insufficient
            appreciation and consensus on among other issues, the
            tariff, and the duration and exclusiveness conditions of the
            concession agreement. Moreover, even after the agreement had
            been signed, disagreements persisted about the timing and
            size of investments, source and cost of finance/loans,
            tariffs, earnings and efficiency/performance standards. The
            project suffered from an unrealistic timeframe for the
            implementation of the legal and regulatory reform. The
            implementation of the regulatory framework and entity was
            crucial for the success of this power/water project, but was
            designed and supported under a different International
            Development Association (IDA)-financed project, which
            created some difficulties during implementation. Putting in
            place robust and realistic tariff adjustment mechanisms is
            still essential for the viability of the power and water
            sectors. The issue of affordability, for the poorest
            consumers, has been a significant one at several points in
            the implementation of this project.

repnme.cdata!:
Cape Verde - Energy and Water Sector Reform
            and Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Energy and Water Sector Reform and
            Development Project will increase private sector
            participation in the infrastructure sectors, and improve
            social development. In pursuit of stable macroeconomic
            frameworks, policy reforms will be consolidated, and,
            poverty alleviation accelerated. The project will improve
            the supply of power, water, and sanitation systems,
            increasing the operational and end-user efficiency of
            infrastructure sectors. Renewable energy sources will be
            developed, as will a sound management of water resources.
            The components of the project call for: 1) reforms and
            development of the power sector, supporting privatization of
            public entities, its financial restructuring, and, the
            implementation of regulatory and legal frameworks.
            Demand-side management and energy efficient equipment are
            included as marginal economic extension and environmental
            liability mitigation; 2) renewable energy promotion and
            development, decentralizing wind/solar photovoltaic systems;
            3) reform and development of the water sector, supporting
            new regulatory/legal frameworks, new autonomous water
            companies, and, extending water networks; 4) sanitation
            development and improvement, through the construction of
            wastewater reuse systems; and, 5) Project
            coordination/management, supporting institutional strengthening.
